content: Asian pancake ***Martabak manis*** (lit. 'sweet [murtabak](/wiki/Murtabak)') also known as ***[Apam](/wiki/Appam) balik*** (lit. 'turnover pancake'; [Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): أڤم باليق‎‎‎), ***terang bulan*** (lit. 'moonlight'), **peanut pancake**, or ***ban jian kueh*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 曼煎粿; [Tâi-lô](/wiki/T%C3%A2i-u%C3%A2n_L%C3%B4-m%C3%A1-j%C4%AB_Phing-im_Hong-%C3%A0n): *bān-tsian-kué*), is a sweet dessert originating in [Fujian cuisine](/wiki/Fujian_cuisine) which now consists of many varieties at specialist roadside stalls or restaurants throughout [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). It can also be found in [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong) as ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 冷糕), [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan) as ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 麥仔煎), [Southern Thailand](/wiki/Southern_Thailand) as ***khanom thang taek*** (ขนมถังแตก) and in the [Sulu Archipelago](/wiki/Sulu_Archipelago), [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines) as ***tarambulan***. ## Origins Part of a series on[Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)[Regional cuisines](/wiki/Chinese_regional_cuisine)Four Great Traditions - [Chuan (Sichuan)](/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine) - [Lu (Shandong)](/wiki/Shandong_cuisine) - [Yue (Guangdong)](/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine) - [Huaiyang (Jiangsu)](/wiki/Huaiyang_cuisine) Eight Great Traditions (+all above) - [Anhui](/wiki/Anhui_cuisine) - [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian_cuisine) - [Hunan](/wiki/Hunan_cuisine) - [Zhejiang](/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine) Ten Great Traditions (+all above) - [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing_cuisine) - [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai_cuisine) Twelve Great Traditions (+all above) - [Henan](/wiki/Henan_cuisine) - [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi_cuisine) Fourteen Great Traditions (+all above) - [Hubei](/wiki/Hubei_cuisine) - [Liaoning](/wiki/Liaoning_cuisine) Sixteen Great Traditions (+all above) - [Tianjin](/wiki/Tianjin_cuisine) - [Yunnan](/wiki/Yunnan_cuisine) New Eight Great Traditions - [Gansu](/wiki/Gansu_cuisine) - [Hangzhou](/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine#Style) - [Jilin](/wiki/Jilin_cuisine) - [Liaoning](/wiki/Liaoning_cuisine) - [Ningbo](/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine#Style) - [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi_cuisine) - [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai_cuisine) - [Shanxi](/wiki/Shanxi_cuisine) Beijing and the vicinity - [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing_cuisine) - [Imperial](/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine) - [Aristocrat](/wiki/Chinese_aristocrat_cuisine) - [Tianjin](/wiki/Tianjin_cuisine) Other regional styles - [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_cuisine) - [Guangxi](/wiki/Guangxi_cuisine) - [Guizhou](/wiki/Guizhou_cuisine) - [Hainan](/wiki/Hainan_cuisine) - [Haipai](/wiki/Haipai_cuisine) - [Hakka](/wiki/Hakka_cuisine) - [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong_cuisine) - [Jiangxi](/wiki/Jiangxi_cuisine) - [Macanese](/wiki/Macanese_cuisine) - [Manchu](/wiki/Manchu_cuisine) - [Northeastern](/wiki/Northeastern_Chinese_cuisine) - [Putian (Henghwa)](/wiki/Putian_cuisine) - [Qinghai](/wiki/Qinghai_cuisine) - [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwanese_cuisine) - [Tibetan](/wiki/Tibetan_cuisine) - [Xinjiang](/wiki/Xinjiang_cuisine) Overseas cuisine - [Australia](/wiki/Australian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Britain](/wiki/British_Chinese_cuisine) - [Burma](/wiki/Burmese_Chinese_cuisine) - [Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Canada](/wiki/Canadian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean_Chinese_cuisine) - [Philippines](/wiki/Filipino_Chinese_cuisine) - [India](/wiki/Indian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Indonesia](/wiki/Chinese_Indonesian_cuisine) - [Japan](/wiki/Japanese_Chinese_cuisine) - [Latin America](/wiki/Chinese_Latin_American_cuisine) - [Perú](/wiki/Chifa) - [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Chinese_cuisine) - [Korea](/wiki/Korean_Chinese_cuisine) - [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_cuisine) - [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_Chinese_cuisine) - [Stir frying](/wiki/Stir_frying) - [Double steaming](/wiki/Double_steaming) - [Red cooking](/wiki/Red_cooking) See also - [Customs and etiquette](/wiki/Customs_and_etiquette_in_Chinese_dining) - [List of Chinese desserts](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_desserts) - [List of Chinese dishes](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_dishes) - [List of Chinese restaurants](/wiki/List_of_Chinese_restaurants) - [List of restaurants in China](/wiki/List_of_restaurants_in_China) - Asia portal - China portal - Taiwan portal - Hong Kong portal - Singapore portal - Malaysia portal - v - t - e The invention has been attributed, though without evidence, to [Zuo Zongtang](/wiki/Zuo_Zongtang), a military leader of the late [Qing dynasty](/wiki/Qing_dynasty). In 1855, the army of the [Taiping Heavenly Kingdom](/wiki/Taiping_Heavenly_Kingdom) invaded the [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian) region and General Zuo was appointed to lead an army to crush the rebels. To provide the soldiers with food without interfering in the life of local people, General Zuo is said to have decided to switch from the flatbread which was eaten together with spring onion and chilli sauce, to a pancake that used locally sourced and mass-produced ground cane sugar and peanut as filling. The recipe does seem to have spread throughout the Fujian region, especially around [Quanzhou](/wiki/Quanzhou) and later on throughout Southeast China. It was brought south into Southeast Asia or [Nanyang](/wiki/Nanyang_(region)) by [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) and [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people) immigrants, especially to [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), and merchants spread it to neighbouring regions. In Indonesia, this dish originated in [Bangka Belitung Islands](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung_Islands) by ethnic Chinese ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) and [Khek](/wiki/Khek)) and it was named “Hok Lo Pan” which translates to “[Hoklo](/wiki/Hoklo) ethnicity’s cake.” Its traditional topping includes sugar and sesame seeds. Martabak manis have different names in different regions. In West Borneo, it is called *apam pinang*, similar to Malaysia's *apam balik*. In [Central Java](/wiki/Central_Java), *martabak manis* is referred to as *kue Bandung* which means [Bandung](/wiki/Bandung) cake. The origin of *kue Bandung* started when a man from [Bangka Belitung](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung), opened a Martabak manis stall beside a “Bandung Noodle” stall. ## Other names The dessert is also known by various names in different languages, depending on the region. ### Indonesia - *Terang Bulan*, (lit. 'moonlight') refer to the big round pancake, prior to folding, resembling the shape of a full moon, ([East Java](/wiki/East_Java), [Lesser Sunda Islands](/wiki/Lesser_Sunda_Islands), Southern [Kalimantan](/wiki/Kalimantan), [North Kalimantan](/wiki/North_Kalimantan), [East Kalimantan](/wiki/East_Kalimantan), [Sulawesi](/wiki/Sulawesi), [Maluku](/wiki/Maluku_Islands) and [Western New Guinea](/wiki/Western_New_Guinea)) - *Martabak Manis*, lit. 'sweet martabak' (Southern [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra), [Banten](/wiki/Banten_(province)), [Jakarta](/wiki/Jakarta), [West Java](/wiki/West_Java), most of [Central Java](/wiki/Central_Java) (except [Semarang](/wiki/Semarang)) and [Yogyakarta](/wiki/Special_Region_of_Yogyakarta)) - *Kue Bandung* (in Semarang, Central Java)[*citation needed*] - *Martabak Bangka* ([North Sumatra](/wiki/North_Sumatra) and [Riau Archipelago](/wiki/Riau_Archipelago)) - *Martabak Bandung* ([West Sumatra](/wiki/West_Sumatra)) - *Apam Pinang* (in [West Kalimantan](/wiki/West_Kalimantan)) - *Apam Keubeu* (in [Aceh](/wiki/Aceh)) - *Hok Lo Pan* (福佬粄) (in [Bangka Belitung Islands](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung_Islands) and [Batam](/wiki/Batam_Island)); ### Malaysia and Singapore - *Ban Jian Kueh* ([Tâi-lô](/wiki/T%C3%A2i-u%C3%A2n_L%C3%B4-m%C3%A1-j%C4%AB_Phing-im_Hong-%C3%A0n): *bān-tsian-kué*) (Hokkien, in general for both countries) - *Dai Gau Min* (大塊麵) (Cantonese, in [Perak](/wiki/Perak)) - *Chin Loong Pau* (煎弄包) (Cantonese, in [Kuala Lumpur](/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur)/[Selangor](/wiki/Selangor)) - *Kap Piang* 合餅 (Hakka, in [Sabah](/wiki/Sabah)) - *Mak Pan* 麥粄 (Hakka, in general for both countries) - *Apam [Pulau Pinang](/wiki/Penang)* (Malay, in [Penang](/wiki/Penang)) - *Kuih Haji* (Malay, in certain areas) - *Apam Balik* (Malay, in certain areas) - *Apong* (Malay, in [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan)) - *Apang Balek* (Malay, in [Terengganu](/wiki/Terengganu) and in certain areas of [Pahang](/wiki/Pahang)) - *Apom Balek* (Malay, in [Kedah](/wiki/Kedah)) - *Terang Bulan* (Malay, in [Sabah](/wiki/Sabah)) ### Brunei - *Kuih Malaya/Singapura* (Malay, in Brunei), named during the colonial era when masses of Chinese emigrants went to the region in places such as Singapore ### China - 滿煎糕 ### Hong Kong - 冷糕 (Cantonese) - 砂糖夾餅 (Cantonese) ### Singapore - *Ban Jian Kueh* (Hokkien, Singapore) - *Min Chiang Kueh/Min Jiang Kueh* (Teochew, in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)) - *Peanut Pancake* (麵煎粿) (Singapore) ### Taiwan - 麥仔煎 (Taiwanese Hokkien) ### Philippines - *Tarambulan/Tarang Bulan/Terang Bulan/Apam/Apam Saba/Apam Sabah* (in [Tawi-Tawi](/wiki/Tawi-Tawi), [Sulu](/wiki/Sulu), [Basilan](/wiki/Basilan) and [Zamboanga](/wiki/Zamboanga_City)) - *Muslim hotcake* ([Chavacano](/wiki/Chavacano)) ## Description The pancake's [batter](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) is made from a mixture of flour, eggs, sugar, baking soda, [coconut milk](/wiki/Coconut_milk) and water. The batter is cooked upon a thick round iron frying pan in plenty of palm [margarine](/wiki/Margarine) to avoid it sticking to the pan. Then other ingredients are sprinkled as filling; the most common or traditional is crushed peanut granules with sugar and sweetcorn kernels (available from cans), but modern innovations such as chocolate sprinkles and cheddar cheese are also available. Then, the pancake is folded (hence the name: "turnover pancake") and cut into several pieces. In Indonesia there is a smaller version made with smaller pan, they are called *martabak mini* or *terang bulan mini*. The texture of the apam balik can vary depending on the amount of batter and type of pan used, from one that is akin to a crispier form of [crumpets](/wiki/Crumpets) to small thin light pancake shells that break when bitten (the latter is usually called *apam balik nipis*, 'thin apam balik'). There is a [Peranakan](/wiki/Peranakan) variant, the *apom balik*, that closely resembles the Indonesian *[Serabi](/wiki/Serabi)*. - [List of pancakes](/wiki/List_of_pancakes) - [List of stuffed dishes](/wiki/List_of_stuffed_dishes) - [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Dosai](/wiki/Dosa_(food)) - [Crumpet](/wiki/Crumpet) - [Dorayaki](/wiki/Dorayaki) Portals: - Food - China - Indonesia - Malaysia - Singapore
title: Martabak manis
